Perspective Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction to ammonia: A perspective on Fe/Cu-containing catalysts Lili Chen a Yanheng Hao a Jianyi Chu a Song Liu b Fenghua Bai a * Wenhao Luo a * a Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot 010021, Inner Mongolia, China Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Inner Mongolia University Inner Mongolia Hohhot 010021 China Inner Mongolia Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Physics of Rare Earth Materials, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot 010021, Inner Mongolia, China b Chemical Engineering and Resource Utilization, College of Chemistry, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, Heilongjiang, China Chemical Engineering and Resource Utilization College of Chemistry Northeast Forestry University Harbin Heilongjiang 150040 China Chemical Engineering and Resource Utilization, College of Chemistry, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, Heilongjiang, China * Corresponding author Electrocatalytic reduction reaction of nitrate (NO3RR) to ammonia is becoming ever more pivotal for the sustainable production of NH3, alleviating the nitrate pollution and even for rebalancing the nitrogen cycle globally. Considerable efforts have been devoted to the rational development of catalyst systems in electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, and Fe/Cu-containing catalysts have shown significant advantages and are currently in the spotlight which have addressed remarkable attention and academic interest. In this Perspective, we first briefly discuss the possible reaction pathways of electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. Emphasis is put on the three catalyst approaches for enhancing the NO3RR performance, based on the selected case studies of the most representative Fe/Cu-containing catalysts. Furthermore, this Perspective assesses the recent progress on the utility and application of the state-of-the-art in situ characterization technologies applied in recent showcases of electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, with a special focus on spectroscopies. Finally, the open challenges and outlook regarding the rational design of efficient electrocatalysts, the development of correlative in situ characterization technologies and the further coupling promising reactions for production of value-added products are examined for inspiring the future work. Graphical Abstract This perspective highlights the recent developments of Fe/Cu-containing catalysts and in situ characterization in electrocatalytic NO3RR with the state-of-the-art studies, and presents the opportunities and outlook for guiding future directions and inspiring further developments. Keywords Electrocatalysis Nitrate reduction reaction Ammonia synthesis Fe/Cu-containing catalyst In situ characterization 1 Introduction Ammonia is one of the key chemicals and indispensable feedstocks with versatile applications in modern industries, such as fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, metallurgy, refrigeration, explosives, textiles, etc. [1,2]. Additionally, ammonia is also deemed as one of the most promising energy carriers with the carbon-neutral property and high energy density [3]. Recently, the ammonia synthesis at industrial-scale still heavily relies on the commercial Haber-Bosch process, which is quite energy-intensive and normally catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts and operated under harsh conditions, for example, high temperatures (400–500 °C) and pressures (150–300 atm) [4,5]. According to a recent survey, more than 2% of the global energy supply and 1% of global CO2 emissions are attributed to ammonia production through the commercial Haber-Bosch process [6]. Therefore, the rising environmental concerns about climate change and the requirements of sustainable development have stimulated the search for an alternative, efficient process for ammonia synthesis utilizing renewable energy inputs. Electrochemical ammonia synthesis methods are attractive and sustainable alternatives for NH3 synthesis using renewable energy. Due to abundant presence of N2 and NH3 production under benign conditions, the electrochemical N2 reduction reaction (NRR) has addressed significant research interest in the past years. Nevertheless, the NRR suffers from a low catalytic activity and selectivity for NH3 production, with a low Faraday efficiency and NH3 yield. Specifically, results of considerable NH3 yields are difficult to achieve and far for practical applications, and the major challenges lie in the high dissociation energy required for activating N≡N (941 kJ mol−1) and the extremely poor solubility of N2 in water (0.66 mmol L−1) under working conditions, together with the occurrence of the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [7–9]. Besides, NO has been considered and conducted as the N source for ammonia production, known as electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (NORR). Albeit activation of NO is more easier than that of N2, still, the solubility of NO is too low in water at an ambient temperature of 25 °C (~1.94 mmol L−1) [10]. This factor strongly decreases its potential for further practical application. In contrast, NO3 − exhibits a much lower activation energy of the N=O bond (204 kJ mol−1) than that of the N≡N bond, as well as a high solubility in water at 25 °C, utilizing NO3 − as the nitrogen source is therefore more attractive and promising for electrochemical NH3 synthesis [11,12]. Besides, NO3 −, recognized as a water-soluble contaminant, is increasingly accumulated in water ecosystems owing to the abuse of artificial nitrogen-containing compounds at a large scale over the past decades, which holds a potential threat to the ecological environment and human health [13–15]. In order to alleviate this issue, various technologies have been attempted to nitrate treatment, including ion exchange, biological denitrification, electrodialysis, reverse osmosis, etc. [13,16]. However, these approaches are not economically feasible as they often require high-energy inputs and high-cost operational processes, and lead to low value-added products, which greatly restrict their further application. Rationally, electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3 is a reasonable and attractive alternative for both sustainable NH3 production and pollutant control of NO3 − species (Fig. 1 ). The NO3RR circumvents a chief obstacle of reactant activation, nevertheless, the complex and cross-connected reaction pathways involving various multielectron transfer routes in different reaction media, still restrict the NH3 production and efficiency. Besides, the competing reactions such as HER and others could complicate the reaction routes and lead to a low selectivity in the NO3RR [15]. Notably, efficient coupling of different reactions to maximize the selectivity towards target products is pivotal in the NO3RR, which often requires the rational design of NO3RR electrocatalysts for choosing the optimal route for the efficient production of NH3. To date, various metal elements, including noble metals (Pt, Pd, Rh, Ir, Ru, etc.) and non-noble transition metals (Ti, Cu, Ni, Fe, Co, In, etc.) [17–20] have been widely studied in electrochemical NO3RR to NH3. Especially, Fe/Cu-containing catalysts are currently in the spotlight, which have addressed great attention and remarkable academic interest owing to their significant advantages in catalytic performances and economic feasibility. Since the year of 1905, Fe has been recognized and known as an efficient catalyst for NH3 synthesis [21]. Besides, major nitrogenase enzymes contain Fe species as the intrinsic active sites for NH3 synthesis [22,23]. Fe-containing catalysts have shown great potential for NH3 synthesis in both industry and nature. Among different mono-transition metals, Cu has shown the highest activity of NH3 production in electrocatalytic NO3RR [24]. Additionally, more and more recent studies show that Cu-containing catalysts appear to be excellent in electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, due to its good conductivity and weak hydrogen evolution ability [25–29]. Noteworthily, the energy levels of the d-orbitals in copper, particularly those with highly occupied d-orbitals, closely align with the lowest unoccupied molecular π* orbitals (LUMO π*) of NO3 −, and thus the rate-determining step of electrocatalytic NO3RR could be facilitated owing to the improved electron transfer on Cu. Therefore, collective knowledge of the state-of-the-art Fe/Cu-containing catalyst systems is indisputably essential and useful for facilitating to implement the green and sustainable NO3RR technology in practical industrial applications. In this Perspective, we first present the possible reaction pathways of electrochemical NO3RR to NH3. The emphasis is on three key catalyst strategies, referring to approaches of utilizing single-atom catalysts, bimetallic catalysts and biomimetic catalysts, for advancing NO3RR performance, which are introduced with selected case studies of the most representative Fe/Cu-containing catalysts. Additionally, in situ characterization technologies that applied in recent studies are described and discussed with specific examples. Finally, perspectives and outlooks on expected future developments in the existing field of electrochemical NO3RR to NH3 are provided. 2 Possible reaction pathways of NO3RR The electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − to NH3 proceeds via an 8e− transfer process with N valence states ranging from +5 in NO3 − to −3 in NH3 (NO3 − + 9H+ + 8e− → NH3 + 3H2O in acidic and neutral electrolytes or NO3 − + 6H2O + 8e− → NH3 + 9OH− in alkaline electrolytes). Several possible nitrogen species can be formed as intermediates/products through the different and complex reaction pathways, such as NO, N2 and N2O [30,31]. The product distribution and reaction pathway of NO3RR highly depend on the composition of electrocatalyst, the applied potential, and the electrolyte conditions. Particularly, high acidic conditions (pH < 0) and a high NO3 − concentration of > 1 mol L−1 can often induce the indirect autocatalytic mechanisms and form various products spontaneously, including NO, NO2, and HNO2 as a result of disproportionation reactions [32,33], which are out of the scope of discussion and thus are excluded here. The detailed roadmap of the electrochemical nitrate reduction pathways is illustrated in Fig. 2 . The first step of NO3RR is the reduction of NO3 − to NO2 − (Path a in Fig. 2), which is recognized and well accepted as the rate-determining step. Subsequently, *NO2 − could be further reduced to *NO. *NO is a key intermediate for steering the selectivity of NO3RR, which can be converted to NH3 by different pathways. One is a continuous charge transfer pathway (Path b in Fig. 2), in which *NO could be consecutively hydrogenated to *NOH, further *NHOH, *NH2OH, and eventually NH3. Koper et al. [34] studied the mechanism of NO3RR on Cu catalysts in a basic or acidic medium using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. They observed the presence of hydroxylamine (NH2OH) during NO3RR in the basic media and proposed such a mechanistic pathway. An alternative pathway for the further conversion of *NO is the adsorbed-hydrogen-mediated pathway, where *NO could be further reduced to *N, and then *NH, *NH2, and finally *NH3 by *H species generated from H2O reduction (Path c in Fig. 2). A recent study on Fe-based catalysts supported this mechanism [35]. In the Path c, the *NO → *N step is considered as the potential determining step (PDS). The adsorbed *N intermediates could easily proceed the N–N coupling reaction to form N2O and N2 (Path d in Fig. 2), compared with hydrogenation reduction. Along with the two proposed pathways, other pathways for *NO conversion could result in the formation of N2O and N2 (Path e in Fig. 2), in which N–N coupling reaction is often involved and competing with H-assisted electroreduction. Once the N–N coupling reaction occurs, the NH3 production decreases owing to the formation of N2 or N2O at the expense of N species. To efficiently improve the NH3 production, the N–N coupling reaction should be suppressed in the pathways of NO3RR. In view of the catalyst design, dispersing active sites into isolated single sites is a promising strategy to prevent the N–N coupling, as the N–N coupling reaction requires active neighboring sites. Besides, the similar thermodynamic potentials between NO3RR and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) enable the inevitable occurrence of HER as the competing reaction, in particular at high current densities. Completely suppressing the competing HER for enhancing the Faradic efficiency of NO3RR is of great challenge yet not necessary. As active hydrogen species produced by HER is indispensable in the consecutive hydrogenation steps to form NH3, and therefore balancing and mediating the dynamic balance between the *H generation and *H consumption with precise control in the electrocatalytic NO3RR are of paramount importance in efficiently enhancing the NH3 production [36]. 3 Advance in Fe/Cu-containing electrocatalysts for NO3RR to NH3 According to the mechanistic discussion of the electrochemical NO3RR, rational design and development of efficient catalysts pose significant challenges owing to the complex reaction network of NO3RR and the diversity of product distribution. Fe/Cu-containing catalysts have been extensively investigated and appeared as the catalysts of the best choice owing to their advantages in economic feasibility and catalytic performance in electrochemical NO3RR to NH3 [37–39]. This section will introduce and highlight three catalyst strategies/approaches for achieving the enhanced electrochemical NO3RR performance with selected case studies of the most representative Fe/Cu-containing catalysts. The performance of recent advanced Fe/Cu-containing electrocatalysts for NO3RR is summarized, and the details are given in Table 1 . 3.1 Single-atom catalysts In view of NO3RR pathways for improving the selectivity of ammonia, the competing route for the formation of N–N bond should be suppressed, which could lead to a decrease in NH3 selectivity owing to the stepwise formation of N2 or N2O. To this end, single-atom catalysts (SACs), with all the metal species dispersed atomically and exhibiting mononuclear metal sites on the support [55–57], can be a good approach for avoiding N–N coupling. Utilizing SACs with isolated active sites can efficiently inhibit the dimerization of N species, suppress the formation of the N–N bond, and thus drive the selectivity towards ammonia in NO3RR. Wang et al. [40] synthesized a Fe SAC for the electrochemical NO3RR by dispersing Fe single atoms incorporated in the porous N-doped carbon support. The as-obtained Fe SAC could afford an optimal NH3 Faradaic efficiency of ~75% and an NH3 yield rate of ~0.46 mmol h−1 cm−2, which is much higher than that of Fe nanoparticle counterparts (Fig. 3(a) ). Such a significantly improved NH3 yield rate could be attributed to the effective suppression of the N–N coupling step owing to the lack of neighboring metal sites. Density functional theory calculations suggest that the Fe SAC indeed contains intrinsically high-efficiency active sites, for example Fe–N4 active sites (inset in Fig. 3(a)), which could show a much lower thermodynamic barriers than that of various Fe nanoparticle counterparts. Yang et al. reported an active copper single-atom catalyst (Cu–N–C) with a well-defined structure of Cu–N4 for NO3RR to NH3 [25]. The Cu–N–C SAC afforded a high NH3 yield rate of 9.23 mg h−1 mg−1 cat and an NH3 selectivity of 94% at −1.5 V (vs. saturated calomel electrode), together with a 100% nitrate conversion, which was much higher than the Cu plate catalyst (Fig. 3(b)). The outstanding performance is linked to the SAC characteristics of Cu–N–C, which significantly reduces the formation of double-nitrogen and toxic nitrite products by suppressing N–N coupling and enhancing nitrite adsorption in the tandem catalysis. 3.2 Bimetallic catalysts To efficiently improve the selectivity towards the desired product of NH3, bimetallic catalysts, which can combine different functionalities for efficiently coupling the involved tandem reactions, are often employed for providing an efficient relay catalysis or even synergistic electrocatalysis. Li et al. [44] successfully prepared a N-doped carbon supported Cu-Ni dual-single-atom catalyst (Cu/Ni-NC) for electrocatalytic NO3RR. The as-obtained Cu/Ni-NC afforded a superior performance with a FE of 97.28%, an NH3 selectivity of 94.84%, and a conversion of 98.5% at −0.70 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) compared with the monometallic SAC counterparts Ni-NC (15.2%, 15.8%, and 15.2%) and Cu-NC (33.2%, 31.8%, and 32.2%) in electrocatalytic NO3RR (Fig. 3(c)). A comprehensive characterization study unveiled a synergistic effect from Cu–Ni dual active sites. This synergy efficiently inhibits the HER and hinders N–N coupling reactions, thus preventing the byproduct formation such as N2 and N2O. A strong electron interaction between Cu and Ni single-atoms played a critical role in improving the electrocatalytic performance of NO3RR. Similarly, Sargent et al. [19] reported to utilize CuNi bimetallic alloys for enhancing the NH3 production in electrocatalytic NO3RR, wherein Cu is responsible for *NO3 adsorption, and Ni functions as the binding site for Hads. Notably, the Cu50Ni50 alloy catalysts attained a six-fold increase in NH3 production compared with the pure Cu at 0 V vs. RHE under an alkaline condition (pH = 14) (Fig. 3(d)). Ni alloying enables upshifts the d-band center of Cu towards the Fermi level and further modulates the adsorption energies of intermediates (i.e. *NO3 −, *NO2, and *NH2) for efficiently coupling the relay catalysis. Besides, Peng et al. [45] prepared a bimetallic PdCu/Cu2O catalyst, which consists of well-dispersed PdCu bimetallic alloys and a thin Cu2O shell, for electrocatalytic NO3RR. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the PdCu/Cu2O hybrids afford significant advances in NH3 selectivity, NO3 − conversion rate, and Faradaic efficiency compared to different Cu2O counterparts. The PdCu alloy structure was found to be essential for the enhanced performance, in which the well-dispersed PdCu bimetallic alloys could efficiently promote the NO3 − reduction and the *N formation, and hinder the generation of the *NOH intermediate, thus improving the selectivity to NH3 and FE. Notably, a novel sequential active-site-switching mechanism was proposed by Liu et al. [48] over a TiO2 supported Cu/Fe bimetallic nanoparticles (Cu/Fe-TiO2). The as-obtained Cu/Fe-TiO2 afforded a significantly enhanced performance especially in terms of NH3 production with 4.68 and 2.82 times increase in activity compared with the monometallic counterparts such as Cu-TiO2 and Fe-TiO2, respectively (Fig. 3(f)). A sequential active-site-switching mechanism was proposed for Cu/Fe-TiO2, in which NO3 − initially adsorbs preferentially on the Fe phase, and then shifts to the Cu/Fe interface to catalyze *NO3 to *NH3, and finally, the adsorbed *NH3 switches to the Cu phase. This proposed mechanism was attributed to the enhanced performance of the bifunctional catalyst. Moreover, Lu et al. [49] fabricated a Fe/Cu diatomic catalyst, and achieved a high activity of ~38.5 mA cm−2 at −0.3 V vs. RHE and an excellent selectivity of 92.51% in the electrochemical NO3RR to NH3 under alkaline conditions. The synergistic effects of Fe and Cu dual-atoms weaken N−O bonds and further modulate the adsorption energy of intermediates, leading to low energy barriers for NH3 production. 3.3 Biomimetic catalysts In nature, the conversion of NO3 − to NO2 − and the following reduction of NO2 − to NH3 are catalyzed by the nitrate reductase and the nitrite reductase, respectively. Inspired by the merits of these biological tandem catalysis, constructing enzyme-like nanomaterials for NO3RR to NH3 is of great significance and attraction. Lu et al. [50] constructed a novel nanozyme catalyst by mimicking the iron active sites of nitrate reductase, denoted as FeNPs@MXene for NO3RR (Fig. 4(a) ). A confinement effect of chloride size on facilitating the FeOOH nanoshuttle formation was proposed. Charge transfer can be facilitated by the built-in electric field obtained between FeOOH and MXene, resulting into an improved NO3RR performance. The resultant Fe NPs@MXene catalyst could achieve up to a nitrate conversion of 97.8% and an NH3 selectivity of 76.8%. Cu-type nitrite reductases obtained in Rhizobium appear to be one of the most important nitrogenases, which possess two kinds of copper active centers, which act as electron donor center (T1Cu) and catalytic center (T2Cu) respectively. By simulating the bifunctional moieties of Cu-type nitrite reductases, Sun et al. [51] fabricated CuCo alloy nanosheets via a one-step electro-deposition route (Fig. 4(b)). Generally, Cu-based NO3RR electrocatalysts suffer from the accumulation of NO2 − owing to the slow kinetics of *NO2 − hydrogenation to *NH3. However, alloying Cu with Co proves to be efficient for enhancing the hydrogenation of *NO2 to NH3 on Cu/Co bifunctional catalysts in NO3RR, owing to Co sites having excellent protons’ adsorption (*H) capacity. For the optimal Cu50Co50 catalyst, *H can be rapidly adsorbed on the Co sites suppressing the adsorption of NOx, and then the adsorbed *H could further react with the adsorbed *NO x on the nearby Cu sites to facilitate an efficient tandem catalysis. Additionally, inspired by the tandem nitrate electrocatalysis in nature, Schuhmann et al. [53] achieved high NO3RR activity even at low overpotentials over a core-shell Cu/CuO x -Co/CoO bifunctional (CuCoSP) tandem catalyst by combining two cooperative intermediate moieties (core-shell Cu/CuO x and Co/CoO) into one catalyst system, which was prepared via a facile phase-separation method driven electrochemically (Fig. 4(c)). The specific nanorod array configuration of CuCoSP can provide a more effective highway for charge and mass transfer in the NO3RR process, which could be beneficial to the superior performance of CuCoSP for NO3RR. CuCoSP exhibits a significantly higher ammonia yield at low overpotentials, approximately 45 times higher than that of CoSP, as well as two orders of magnitude higher than CuSP. Those validate the exceptional intrinsic performance of CuCoSP. The presence of the complementary Cu- and Co-based moieties were responsible for the high activity of CuCoSP: Cu-based phases catalyzes the reduction of NO3 − to NO2 − and Co-based phases catalyzes the further reduction of NO2 − to NH3, implementing the tandem catalysis of NO3RR. Moreover, molecular electrocatalysts possess metal-ligand coordination complexes could simulate the specific architectures/coordination of the active enzymes for electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, which has addressed great attention and scientific efforts [58–61]. Notably, Wang et al. [54] tried to simulate the specific structure of enzymes with highly active metal species supported on protein scaffolds. Cu was incorporated into an organic molecular of 3,4,9,10- perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (PTCDA) to form a Cu-based solid catalyst, which could afford a maximum Faradaic efficiency of 85.9% in electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. Such good performance was mainly attributed to efficiently inhibiting HER and simultaneously boosting the N–H combination on the properly modulated electronic structure of Cu species, while PTCDA structure can promote the transportation of electrons and protons to Cu species. 4 In situ characterization technologies for NO3RR to NH3 In situ characterization performed under working conditions could track the key intermediates and monitor the dynamic structure evolution of electrocatalysts effectively during catalysis. The electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3 undergoes multiple deoxygenation and hydrogenation processes. These processes result in the generation of various intermediates/products such as NO2 −, NO, N2O, N2, NH2OH and NH3. Moreover, the structure reconstruction of electrocatalysts often occurs during the electrocatalytic process, and unveiling the insights into dynamic evolution of the active species during catalysis is significant for knowledge-driven rational design of efficient electrocatalysts and providing in-depth understandings. Implementing operando characterization often poses significant challenges due to various limitations of different techniques, in particularly when dealing with three-phase catalysis and solid catalysts in an aqueous environment. Hence, conducting in situ characterization, which simulates the reaction conditions at different stages to some extent, emerges as a viable option or alternative to track the dynamic changes during catalysis. Through the integration of complementary in situ characterization studies, it becomes possible to establish correlations and provide a comprehensive understanding of the dynamic evolution with a holistic picture. Online differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) is a technique that is commonly used in electrochemical reaction for the real-time detection of volatile intermediates/products. Zhang et al. [37] synthesized CuO nanowire arrays for NO3RR to unveil the real active phase of Cu-based electrocatalysts during the reaction. They performed online DEMS to detect the molecular intermediates/products and then deduced the reaction pathway of NO3RR. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , the mass-to-charge (m/z) signals at 46, 30, 33, 17 corresponding to NO2, NO, NH2OH and NH3, respectively, were appeared consistently over four consecutive cycles. The results obtained from DEMS allow for revealing the reaction pathway. The N−O bond of *NO3 undergoes gradual spontaneous cleavage, yielding *NO2 and *NO. Subsequently, a hydrogenation step transforms *NO into *NOH, and further hydrogenation leads to the formation of *NH2OH, ultimately transforming into *NH3. However, DEMS still faces limitations in detecting some liquid and ionic products that are difficult to volatilize. For vibration spectroscopy, a trade-off between signal resolution and spectroscopic data acquisition is essential for the successful application of in situ spectroscopy techniques in the electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. Recently, in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy has been applied for the Cu-N-C SAC to explore the chemical states and coordination environment of Cu species and its structural evolution at different applied potential in the electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. With the aid of complementary high-resolution electron microscopy, Wang et al. [42] revealed that the as-prepared Cu-N4 single-atom sites underwent a successive restructuring process during the electrochemical NO3RR to NH3, from Cu-N4 structure to Cu-N3, further to near-metallic Cu single atoms, and eventually to agglomerate Cu nanoparticles (Figs. 5(b), (c)) at an overpotential range of 0.00 to –1.00 V vs. RHE. Notably, the ammonia production rate was significantly enhanced when the potential-driven Cu0 nanoparticles were generated, indicating that the intrinsic active sites of Cu0 nanoparticles, rather than the Cu-N x single-atom species as proposed in the previous literature [42]. This work shows the paramount importance of in situ characterization for identifying the intrinsic active species, which could be masked by the potential-induced restructuring during electrolysis, and thus lead to a plausible conclusion of single-atom species as the active sites. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy is an excellent tool for studying the detailed molecular information and exploring the reaction mechanism. Particularly, attenuated total reflection (ATR)-FTIR spectroscopy possesses a high interfacial sensitivity, which allows the identification of species changes at a molecular level and monitoring the dynamic interfacial evolution under the real electrocatalytic conditions. For example, by tracking the intermediates with in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy over time, Zhou et al. [62] investigated the mechanism of the electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3 (Fig. 5(d)). In situ ATR-FTIR results showed the appearance of −NH2 and NH3 species at the gradual consumption of NO3 − over time. The peaks corresponding to NO− and monodentate nitrite (M-O-N-O) could also be detected, and thus the authors deduced the possible NO3RR reaction pathway. Owing to the advantages of Raman spectroscopy for avoiding the interference of spectral features derived from an aqueous liquid phase, in situ Raman spectroscopy measurements were often conducted to get insights into tracking the chemical information and evolution of intermediates in the electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. Li et al. [47] have conducted in situ Raman spectroscopy to obtain insights into the reduction process over Cu and Ru1Cu10 alloy catalyst in a mixed solution of 0.1 mol L−1 KNO3 and 1 mol L−1 KOH (Figs. 5(e) and (f)) in the potential range from 0.4 to –0.2 V (vs. RHE). The results of in situ Raman spectroscopy reflected that the generation, desorption, adsorption and conversion of NO2 − to NH3 proceed via a relay catalysis for the Ru1Cu10 alloy catalyst, and revealed that the formation of RuCu alloy could promote the catalytic activity in the electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, corroborated by theoretical calculation. 5 Perspective and outlook Electrocatalytic NO3RR is arguably at the spotlight of electrocatalysis, which has gained a growing interest recently and has demonstrated significant potential [63–67]. Still, the future opportunities for the development of electrocatalytic NO3RR encompass three major challenges (Fig. 6 ), with respect to (1) rational design of high-performing electrocatalysts, especially with biomimicking design strategies for constructing multifunctions and with the long-term stability; (2) further exploration of advanced in situ/operando characterization methods/techniques at the solid-liquid interfaces for unravelling the intrinsic active species and their dynamic evolution during catalysis; (3) the sustainable production of value-added chemicals by further integrating/coupling electrocatalytic NO3RR process with other promising reactions/processes, such as CO2 reduction for urea, amination reaction for amines/amino acids and biomass conversion for other value-added chemicals. Electrocatalysts play an essential role in efficiently improving the electrocatalytic NO3RR performance. With the development of material science, SACs and bimetallic catalysts have addressed an on-going attention in electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3 owing to the improvement of various physical and chemical characteristics resulting from the synergistic effect raised between various active sites. For rational design and development of highly efficient electrocatalysts, the pursuit of the ideal electrocatalysts with key parameters, including high FE and NH3 yields at low overpotential, under low concentration and neutral pH conditions, is essential and utmost important. Radar charts of the electrocatalytic NO3RR performances have been shown for three catalyst approaches according to these five key parameters (Fig. 7 ). Apparently, the biomimetic catalyst approach has shown comprehensive advantages, especially in terms of a lower initial nitrate concentration, and superior NH3 yield rate, compared with the SAC and bimetallic catalyst approaches. Hence, biomimetic catalyst approach by mimicking of enzyme structures is very attractive and promising, which deserves to be further exploited for approaching the ideal NO3RR electrocatalysts. Notably, nanoreactor electrocatalysts with confined nanoarchitectures and optimized the mass transportation, could construct enzyme-like specific architectures/nanostructures by imitating the active sites of nitrate/nitrite reductase, and thus achieve a synergistic performance in terms of specific selectivity. Hollow nanoreactor catalysts with biomimetic catalytic functions can indeed simulate the structures and functions of cells or organelles [68], which have received extensive attention and are of great significance and attraction in electrocatalysis [69–71]. In principle, combining spatially confined nanoreactor with bio-inspired centers for tandem catalysis would offer an exciting opportunity to fabricate advanced catalysts with an improved and even previously unattained NO3RR performance, in analogy to enzymatic systems. The biomimicking design of the electrocatalysts holds a great potential to construct multicomponent catalysts for efficient tandem catalysis. Besides, another key parameter of long-term stability should not be overlooked in the electrocatalytic NO3RR, as excellent catalyst stability and performance for maintaining long-term electrolysis is still lacking at the current stage. To this end, stability after a continuous electrocatalysis of > 100 h should be shown [72,73], rather than stability shown in various and incomparable forms. Future studies on biomimetic catalyst approaches for attaining high-performing catalysts should be noted with all the key parameters comprehensively, for confirming the validity of the high-performing electrocatalysts in electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. Although many catalysts have shown superior catalytic performance in the electrochemical NO3RR process, their catalytic mechanisms and reaction processes remain inadequately elucidated, often relying solely on theoretical calculations without robust experimental evidence. Exploration of in situ characterization thus poses paramount importance for advancing the understanding of the intrinsic active species and their dynamic evolution at the solid-liquid interfaces, which appears as a cutting-edge field of opportunities and challenges. Although progresses have been made with the application of a series of implemented in situ characterization techniques in the electrochemical NO3RR process, there is still quite a space for utilizing in situ/operando techniques to bridge the gap between the experimental reactivity and information gained from ex situ characterization. Major limitations and challenges of the application of in situ characterization techniques lie in obtaining a decent interfacial sensitivity with high spatial and temporal resolutions. For example, XAS could provide bulk signals which may overwhelm those from the surface/interfacial sites. The discrimination of XAS against lighter atoms generally makes in situ XAS insensitive to most species (water and organic species) within the electric double layer. In contrast, surface-enhanced vibrational spectroscopies like surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and surface-enhanced infrared spectroscopy (SEIRS) offer greater insights due to their heightened sensitivity at the interface. The strong IR absorption of water usually presents a considerable obstacle in aqueous electrocatalytic systems. Nevertheless, in situ ATR-SEIRS could efficiently mitigate this issue and continuously gain an increasingly popular and powerful method in modern electrocatalysis. SERS can be applied in in situ characterization for efficiently avoiding the interference of water's spectral signals owing to a relatively weak Raman scattering effect [74]. Nonetheless, the effectiveness of SER signals is constrained by the diminished Raman scattering effect, necessitating a more extended acquisition time for signal collection compared to SEIRS. This limitation makes SERS less suitable, particularly when aiming to detect short-lived intermediates. Each single in situ characterization technology cannot provide the comprehensive information owing to limitations of each technology. Combining multiple and complimentary in situ characterization technologies could improve the interfacial sensitivity in spatial and temporal resolutions, which poses advantages for future in situ spectroscopic investigation, especially in the development of innovative techniques that allow for both time-/space-resolution, enabling the identification of transient species and intermediates at the solid-liquid interfaces. Those remain challenging but essential for deepening the understanding of how electrocatalysis unfolds. The limitations thereof also represent opportunities to further guide the future research direction of advancing the design of electrocatalysts and the understanding of electrocatalytic NO3RR processes. In comparison with the traditional ammonia synthesis process, the electrocatalytic NO3RR process does not involve the use of external H2 and could be integrated with ideally locally generated electricity from sustainable sources (i.e. wind and solar energy). Although the electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3 holds advantages conceptually, the development of the electrocatalytic NO3RR process is still a challenge and limited for the sustainable large-scale NH3 production under practical conditions. The different wastewater supply with various standards of nitrate concentration, efficient capture of NH3 produced locally and ensuring the high performance and long-term stability of electrocatalysts should be all fully addressed for evaluation of the feasibility of this process. Besides, NH3 itself is also pollutant in water, and it is essential to consider NH3 recovery and its further valorization after the electrochemical NO3RR to NH3. Although a set of approaches for the removal of NH3, such as acid adsorption, struvite precipitation, membrane enrichment, microalgae and photosynthetic bacteria, etc. have been proposed, these methods are often relatively complex and time-consuming [75]. In view of nitrate removal in water treatments, N2 is the more desirable and favorable end-product compared with NH3 during NO3RR electrocatalysis, since ammonia predominantly dissolves in the electrolyte of aqueous systems and poses separation problems. To this end, attention should be paid to the production of value-added chemicals by the further electrocatalytic C−N coupling with the locally produced NH3 in NO3RR process. Recent studies have opened up the field of sustainable electrocatalytic NO3RR to value-added chemicals, such as urea by coupling NO3RR with the reduction of CO2 [76–79], and amines/amino acids by utilizing the NH3 for consecutive amination reactions [80,81]. Integrating electrocatalytic NO3RR process with other promising processes, i.e. biomass conversion, for the value-added chemicals (amines/amino acids) beyond NH3, is worthy of further exploration for enhancing the economics of the electrocatalytic NO3RR. Although significant achievements have been achieved for the electrochemical NO3RR to NH3 over Fe/Cu-containing catalysts, further improvements are still required and noted for accelerating the future research in this field. Efficient and rigorous experimental protocols are required to verify the accuracy and reproducibility of the as-obtained data, and to ensure that the future study of electrocatalytic NO3RR is more reliable and meaningful. For example, ambient ammonia contamination is an inevitable interference factor for the quantification of NH3. A strict and careful calculation of nitrogen balance that includes all nitrogen-containing species should be provided to close the mass balance. Besides, experimental parameters, encompassing the electrochemical cell setup, electrolyte purity, catalyst preparation, operational conditions (concentration, temperature, pressure, flow rate, rotation speed, etc.), potential human experimental variations, etc. can also significantly influence the obtained electrocatalytic NO3RR performance, which might lead to inaccurate, non-repeatable results, and even misleading conclusions when the experiments were not conducted properly and carefully. Therefore, standard protocols with rigorous and efficient experimental methods, and transparent reports with effective documentation are highly required for the entire community of the electrocatalytic NO3RR. Finally, we hope that those considerations could be of aid and guide for the rational design of highly efficient electrocatalysts and the in-depth understanding of dynamic mechanism, which can facilitate the early realization of practical applications of electrocatalytic NO3RR by utilization of renewable energy. Ed., 2021, 60, 21943–21951. Fenghua Bai (College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University) obtained her Ph.D. in 2008 from Inner Mongolia University (China). Since 2008, she has been working in Inner Mongolia University as an associate professor. In 2012, she was a visiting scholar at University of Exeter in UK. She has been a vice dean of School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University since 2015. She was appointed as an associate editor of Mater. Today Sustain. since 2023. Her research interests lie in the development of new catalytic materials for the sustainable production of chemicals from biomass, carbon dioxide, syngas or waste streams. Wenhao Luo (College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University) obtained his Ph.D. in Inorganic Chemistry and Catalysis in 2014 from Utrecht University (Netherlands), supervised by Prof. Bert Weckhuysen and Prof. Pieter Bruijnincx. Afterwards, he worked with Prof. Johannes Lercher as a postdoctoral fellow at Technical University of Munich (Germany). In 2016–2023, he joined Prof. Tao Zhang's group in Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (DICP) as an associate professor. He was a visiting scholar in the group of Prof. Andrew Beale in 2017 at University College London (UK). He became a full professor at Inner Mongolia University in 2023, where he has worked since then on heterogeneous catalysis, environmental catalysis, operando spectroscopic characterization, renewable energy, and sustainable chemistry.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic reduction reaction of nitrate (NO3RR) to ammonia is becoming ever more pivotal for the sustainable production of NH3, alleviating the nitrate pollution and even for rebalancing the nitrogen cycle globally. Considerable efforts have been devoted to the rational development of catalyst systems in electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, and Fe/Cu-containing catalysts have shown significant advantages and are currently in the spotlight which have addressed remarkable attention and academic interest. In this Perspective, we first briefly discuss the possible reaction pathways of electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3. Emphasis is put on the three catalyst approaches for enhancing the NO3RR performance, based on the selected case studies of the most representative Fe/Cu-containing catalysts. Furthermore, this Perspective assesses the recent progress on the utility and application of the state-of-the-art in situ characterization technologies applied in recent showcases of electrocatalytic NO3RR to NH3, with a special focus on spectroscopies. Finally, the open challenges and outlook regarding the rational design of efficient electrocatalysts, the development of correlative in situ characterization technologies and the further coupling promising reactions for production of value-added products are examined for inspiring the future work.
